Journal.Title: Rapid communications in mass spectrometry : RCM

Article.ArticleTitle: Determination of the triple oxygen isotopic composition of tropospheric ozone in terminal positions using a multistep nitrite-coated filter-pack system.

AbstractText: The triple oxygen isotopic composition (Δ<sup>17</sup> O) of tropospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ) is a useful tracer for identifying the source and is essential for clarifying the atmospheric chemistry of oxidants. However, the single nitrite-coated filter method is inaccurate owing to the nitrate blank produced through the reaction of nitrite and oxygen compounds other than O<sub>3</sub> .

A multistep nitrite-coated filter-pack system is newly adopted to transfer the O-atoms in terminal positions of O<sub>3</sub> to nitrite on each filter to determine the Δ<sup>17</sup> O of O<sub>3</sub> in terminal positions (denoted as Δ<sup>17</sup> O(O<sub>3</sub> )<sub>term</sub> ). The NO<sub>3</sub> <sup>-</sup> produced by this reaction is chemically converted into N<sub>2</sub> O, and continuous-flow isotope ratio mass spectrometry (CF-IRMS) is used to determine the oxygen isotopic compositions.

The reciprocal of the NO<sub>3</sub> <sup>-</sup> quantities on the nitrite-coated filters in each sample showed a strong linear relationship with Δ<sup>17</sup> O of NO<sub>3</sub> <sup>-</sup> . Using the linear relation, we corrected the changes in Δ<sup>17</sup> O of NO<sub>3</sub> <sup>-</sup> on the filters. We verified the accuracy of the new method through the measurement of artificial O<sub>3</sub> with known Δ<sup>17</sup> O(O<sub>3</sub> )<sub>term</sub> value that had been determined from the changes in Δ<sup>17</sup> O of O<sub>2</sub> . The Δ<sup>17</sup> O(O<sub>3</sub> )<sub>term</sub> of tropospheric O<sub>3</sub> was in agreement with previous studies.

We accurately determined the δ<sup>18</sup> O and Δ<sup>17</sup> O values of tropospheric O<sub>3</sub> by blank correction using our new method. Measurements of Δ<sup>17</sup> O(O<sub>3</sub> )<sub>term</sub> of the ambient troposphere showed 1.1 ± 0.7‰ diurnal variations between daytime (higher) and nighttime (lower) due likely to the formation of the temperature inversion layer at night.
